Understate: The claim may understate the extent to which the governor encouraged voters to deliver their absentee ballots in-person since mid-September.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it does not provide direct quotes or evidence of the governor explicitly telling voters not to mail their ballots.
Problematic assumption: The claim makes the problematic assumption that the governor explicitly told voters not to mail their ballots, when in fact she encouraged them to drop off their ballots instead.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation that the governor's intention was to ensure that ballots are counted by encouraging in-person delivery rather than relying on the Postal Service.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the governor did not explicitly tell voters not to mail their ballots, as clarified by the expert's verdict.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not accurately representing the governor's statements and instead paraphrasing them.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the governor's message by implying that she explicitly told voters not to mail their ballots, when she actually encouraged in-person delivery.
